results_summary: MORE led to a 32% greater decrease in opioid dosing compared to the support group control, with increased heart rate variability (HRV) during meditation partially mediating this effect. The results suggest MORE may improve self-regulatory capacity, aiding opioid tapering.
population_specificity: Chronic pain patients on long-term opioid therapy (N = 95).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on the diagnosis, treatment, and management of apathy in Parkinson's disease, including the role of mindfulness as a potential treatment.
results_summary: The review identified mindfulness as one of the treatment methods studied in randomized controlled trials for apathy in Parkinson's disease, though the abstract does not provide specific efficacy results for mindfulness alone.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease and apathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an 8-week mindfulness course could enhance university students' resilience to stress and improve their psychological well-being up to a year later.
results_summary: The mindfulness course (MSS) led to sustained improvements in self-reported psychological distress and mental well-being compared to standard support (SAU) for up to a year, with stronger effects during high-stress periods. No adverse effects related to self-harm or harm to others were reported, and home practice showed positive dose-response effects.
population_specificity: University of Cambridge students without severe mental illness or crisis.
study_duration: 8 weeks, with follow-up assessments up to 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the efficacy and acceptability of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) for military veterans, focusing on psychological symptoms and quality of life.
results_summary: MBIs showed superiority over non-specific controls in improving PTSD, depression, general psychological symptoms, quality of life, and mindfulness at post-treatment, but not physical health. Effects on general psychological symptoms persisted at follow-up, though attrition rates were higher in MBI groups.
population_specificity: Military veterans
study_duration: Mean follow-up of 3.19 months (intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effects of community-based Shotokan karate classes, which combine physical activity and mindfulness, on individuals with mild- to moderate-stage Parkinson's Disease.
results_summary: The study found high adherence and significant improvements in quality of life and wellbeing, with no adverse effects or changes in fall frequency. However, mobility, mood, and cognition did not show significant changes.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild- to moderate-stage Parkinson's Disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) and mindfulness-based meditation (MBM) on pain processing mechanisms in older adults with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The active tDCS and MBM group showed significant pain relief and increased oxyhemoglobin activation in motor and somatosensory cortices, while the sham group did not. The study suggests fNIRS can effectively monitor neural pain mechanisms during nonpharmacological treatments.
population_specificity: Older adults with knee osteoarthritis (19 subjects).
effective_dosage: 10-day active tDCS and MBM regimen (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Relapse Prevention (MBRP) with other treatments (cognitive behavioral relapse prevention and 12-step-based treatment) for substance use outcomes in younger versus older adults.
results_summary: Older adults in MBRP showed significantly higher abstinence rates and lower percent use days compared to those in standard treatments, while younger adults did not show significant differences between treatments.
population_specificity: Adults in substance abuse treatment, divided into younger (below 40) and older (40+) age groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a modified Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) on reducing stress and improving psychological well-being in family caregivers of people with dementia.
results_summary: The modified MBCT significantly improved caregivers' stress, depression, anxiety, and mental health-related quality of life, as well as reduced behavioral and psychological symptoms in care recipients. Increased mindfulness levels in caregivers correlated with improved psychological outcomes.
population_specificity: Family caregivers of people with dementia.
effective_dosage: 7-session modified MBCT over 10 weeks with telephone follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review acute care treatments for migraine, including behavioral medicine techniques like mindfulness.
results_summary: The study mentions that behavioral medicine techniques such as mindfulness have been available for some time and are often helpful in treating migraine, though specific efficacy data is not detailed.
population_specificity: Migraine sufferers (no further specificity provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness in managing psychological stress and disturbances related to hypertension, as well as its impact on blood pressure and mental health awareness.
results_summary: The study measured reductions in psychological scale scores (PHQ-9 and GAD-7) and blood pressure, with results analyzed using multilevel regression and hierarchical linear models, though specific outcomes are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 80 patients with hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test a natural therapy protocol, including Mindfulness Meditation, as an alternative to pharmacological and psychotherapeutic treatments for reducing depression symptoms in individuals not receiving traditional treatment.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in depression symptoms in the experimental group after the intervention, though it could not determine which specific technique was most effective.
population_specificity: Individuals with depression symptoms not receiving pharmacological or psychotherapeutic treatment (n=21).
effective_dosage: Not specified (eight sessions over two months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and analyze seven key factors that influence participants' ability to establish and maintain mindfulness practice at home, using the COM-B model (Capability, Opportunity, Motivation, and Behaviour).
results_summary: The study identified seven factors (Capability: planning/commitment, physical space; Opportunity: social support, teacher relationship; Motivation: readiness for self-care, beliefs, self-efficacy, rewards) that influence mindfulness practice. Practical lessons were drawn for mindfulness teachers to support participants' home practice.
population_specificity: Participants in mindfulness-based programmes (MBPs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and long-term effects of an 8-week MBSR programme on health-related quality of life and quality of work life for primary care health professionals.
results_summary: The intervention group showed higher post-intervention scores for mindfulness, health-related quality of life, mood, and compassion satisfaction, along with reduced burnout. Improvements in mindfulness, mood, and burnout persisted at 12 months.
population_specificity: Primary care health professionals (N=58) in Alicante, Spain.
effective_dosage: 8-week MBSR programme (specific session frequency not detailed).
study_duration: 8 weeks, with follow-ups at 3, 6, 9, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability and preliminary effectiveness of Mind-Body Skills Groups (MBSGs) as a treatment for depressed adolescents in primary care.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in depression scores, mindfulness, self-efficacy, rumination, and suicidal ideation following the MBSG intervention, with continued improvement at follow-up. The program was highly acceptable, and attendance was excellent.
population_specificity: Depressed adolescents in primary care settings.
effective_dosage: Not specified (10-week program, but no dosage details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a brief online mindfulness-based intervention (MI) versus stress management (SM) on first-year college students' happiness, depression, anxiety, stress, and state mindfulness.
results_summary: Both MI and SM conditions led to significant declines in anxiety and stress. MI uniquely increased subjective happiness, while SM uniquely reduced depression.
population_specificity: First-year college students (n=247)

study_goal: To review recent studies on emotion-focused parenting interventions, including mindfulness parenting programs, for their role in preventing and treating mental health difficulties in children, adolescents, and families.
results_summary: The review found that mindfulness parenting programs, among other emotion-focused interventions, effectively target emotional awareness, regulation, and communication, improving parent-child relationships and reducing emotion dysregulation. These interventions showed promise in enhancing healthy emotional functioning.
population_specificity: Children, adolescents, and their families, particularly those experiencing emotion dysregulation or attachment-related challenges.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and potential proof-of-concept of a 4-week positive psychology group intervention (Activating Happiness©) emphasizing mindfulness, self-compassion, and gratitude for cancer survivors and caregivers.
results_summary: The intervention showed high acceptability among participants, with 89% completing all study activities. Benchmarking outcomes against randomized controlled trials revealed comparable effect sizes for mindfulness, self-compassion, anxiety, depression (caregivers and survivors), and pain (survivors).
population_specificity: Cancer survivors (35) and caregivers (14).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on depression, cognition, and immunity in individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) compared to cognitive training.
results_summary: MBSR significantly reduced depressive symptoms at both post-intervention and six-month follow-up, showed a minimal positive effect on psychomotor speed post-intervention, and induced detectable changes in immunological profiles. The intervention was well-accepted, though adherence was lower in those with more severe cognitive decline.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential effectiveness and necessary modifications of mindfulness-based interventions (MBCT/MBSR) for people with cognitive impairments, including dementia.
results_summary: The study found that MBCT and MBSR can be applied with minor modifications (e.g., shortened sessions, memory aids) in cognitively impaired populations, but evidence for their effectiveness in dementia remains lacking due to insufficient empirical studies.
population_specificity: People with cognitive impairments, including stroke, traumatic brain injury, mild cognitive impairment, and dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and feasibility of a brief mindfulness-based program to reduce stress during work hours among health care professionals.
results_summary: The study found that the mindfulness-based intervention significantly reduced stress and anxiety, improved positive affect and state mindfulness, and enhanced mindful self-care compared to the control group. These benefits were sustained at follow-up, though burnout, negative affect, and trait mindfulness levels did not differ between groups.
population_specificity: Full-time health care professionals at the Clinical Center at the National Institutes of Health.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate moderators of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) in improving dyspareunia, reducing pain catastrophizing, and enhancing sexual function in women with provoked vestibulodynia (PVD).
results_summary: Both MBCT and CBT effectively reduced pain, sexual dysfunction, and pain catastrophizing in women with PVD. Treatment credibility, relationship length, and PVD subtype differentially moderated improvements, with MBCT benefiting those with higher credibility, shorter relationships, and secondary PVD, while CBT was more effective for primary PVD and longer relationships.
population_specificity: Women with provoked vestibulodynia (PVD).
study_duration: Treatment outcomes were assessed before and after treatment, and at 6- and 12-month follow-ups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a novel mindfulness intervention (mindfulness combined with interoceptive exposure) could improve upon existing mindfulness interventions and extend therapeutic gains to mechanistic targets in high-stress contexts for at-risk smokers.
results_summary: The study proposed an experimental medicine approach to assess mindfulness intervention's role in addressing lapse-relevant vulnerabilities (low distress tolerance and low working memory capacity) during nicotine-deprivation states, but specific efficacy results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Low-income, low-education smokers undergoing a quit attempt.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of an app-based mindfulness training program on reducing worry and improving sleep in adults with anxiety-related sleep disturbances.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial to test the mechanistic effects of mindfulness training on worry and sleep, but results are not yet reported as this is a study protocol.
population_specificity: Approximately 80 adults with worry that interferes with their sleep.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness questionnaires in measuring changes in mindfulness skills in longitudinal studies of personality disorders (PDs).
results_summary: Most studies (7 out of 10) reported an increase in mindfulness skills, with the FFMQ being the most commonly used and suitable measure. Mindfulness changes were also associated with clinical improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with personality disorders, primarily borderline personality disorder, with limited representation of male patients and other PD types.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review meditation adverse events (MAEs) to investigate their major clinical categories and prevalence.
results_summary: The study found that 8.3% of participants experienced adverse events, with anxiety, depression, and cognitive anomalies being the most common. Adverse events occurred in individuals with no prior history of mental health problems.
population_specificity: Adult samples across experimental, observational, and case studies (total 6703 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions in reducing occupational stress and/or burnout among emergency department staff.
results_summary: Three of the four studies on mindfulness-based interventions reported reduced stress levels, but a meta-analysis of two studies showed a non-significant difference in stress between mindfulness and control groups.
population_specificity: Health personnel working in emergency departments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a mindfulness-based childbirth and parenting program on maternal-fetal attachment among Iranian pregnant women.
results_summary: The mindfulness intervention significantly improved maternal-fetal attachment scores compared to routine care alone, with a notable effect size (0.640). All dimensions of attachment improved in the intervention group except "differentiation of self from the fetus," while the control group showed improvement in only one dimension.
population_specificity: Iranian pregnant women
effective_dosage: Eight 2-hour group sessions once a week and one 3-hour session of silent meditation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility of engaging and retaining veterans with chronic lower back pain in a mindfulness-based intervention (MBCP) and assess clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that 55% of participants attended 5 or more sessions, with some showing clinically meaningful decreases in pain intensity, depressive symptoms, pain bothersomeness, and functional impairment, though retention was challenging.
population_specificity: Veterans with chronic lower back pain (mean age 49.77, 18% women) recruited from a VA Medical Center in the Northeastern US.
effective_dosage: 8-week MBCP course including meditation, gentle yoga, and psychoeducation (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a mindfulness-based intervention adapted for social anxiety disorder (MBI-SAD) with cognitive behavior group therapy (CBGT) for treating social anxiety disorder.
results_summary: CBGT was more effective than MBI-SAD in reducing social anxiety severity, though MBI-SAD showed comparable benefits in improving well-being indicators like depression and self-esteem. The study did not find greater improvements in mindfulness and self-compassion with MBI-SAD compared to CBGT.
population_specificity: Individuals with social anxiety disorder (n = 97, split into MBI-SAD and CBGT groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of spiritual interventions, including mindfulness, in treating insomnia and assess the scientific evidence supporting these interventions.
results_summary: The review found that mindfulness and other spiritual interventions had a positive influence on insomnia, both directly and indirectly, though the evidence was limited due to small sample sizes and reliance on subjective measures.
population_specificity: Individuals with insomnia or associated mental disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal components of the LIFT mobile mindfulness program for ICU survivors, evaluating factors like therapist involvement and dosage.
results_summary: The LIFT intervention reduced distress symptoms more than telephone-based mindfulness or education control in a pilot trial. The current study seeks to optimize the intervention across effect, feasibility, scalability, and cost.
population_specificity: ICU survivors experiencing psychological distress.
effective_dosage: High dose vs. low dose (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine recent neuroscientific findings on the mechanisms by which mindfulness meditation provides pain relief and how these mechanisms differ from placebo and vary with meditative training level.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based therapies reliably reduce chronic pain through psychological, physiological, and neural mechanisms, modulating the evaluation of sensory events. Neuroimaging and randomized control studies confirm that mindfulness meditation reduces both experimental and clinical pain via unique, non-opioidergic mechanisms distinct from placebo, with effects varying by training level.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic pain conditions (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness interventions in managing stress, anxiety, depression, emotional regulation, mindfulness levels, and sleep quality in pregnant women.
results_summary: Mindfulness interventions were beneficial for stress, anxiety, and depression, including in women with a history of depression. There were signs of improvement in emotional regulation and mindfulness levels, but sleep quality was not evaluated.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, including those with a history of depression or experiencing depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify psychosocial mechanisms (including mindfulness) through which yoga reduces stress.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness increased from baseline to post-intervention and was strongly associated with reductions in perceived stress and stress reactivity. Self-compassion was the only mechanism that did not show significant improvement.
population_specificity: 42 participants (62% female, 64% White) in a yoga program for stress reduction.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of mindfulness-based interventions on glycemic control in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in blood glucose or glycated hemoglobin levels between mindfulness intervention and control groups, with very low quality of evidence. Large-scale trials are needed to further assess mindfulness's contribution to glycemic control.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of combined sleep hygiene recommendations and mindfulness on sleep parameters, well-being, anxiety, and match outcomes in high-performance junior tennis players during tournaments.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved sleep duration and bedtime timing, with small positive effects on mood and cognitive anxiety, but no impact on match performance outcomes.
population_specificity: High-performance junior tennis players

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of an eight-week mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) program on counseling self-efficacy and related psychological and neuro-physiological measures among counseling trainees.
results_summary: The study found that MBCT significantly improved empathy, self-compassion, stress reduction, and counseling self-efficacy, supported by psychological and neuro-physiological evidence post-intervention. However, differences between groups diminished after crossover, with carry-over effects and improvements noted in both groups at follow-up. Mindfulness was the strongest predictor of counseling self-efficacy, followed by reduced psychological distress and self-compassion.
population_specificity: Undergraduate counseling trainees (n = 50, split into MBCT and waitlist control groups).
effective_dosage: Structured eight-week MBCT program (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Eight weeks, with follow-up at six months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the clinical effectiveness of a 1-week electronic mindfulness course on prenatal depression and anxiety in hospitalized, high-risk pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in state anxiety levels and pregnancy-related anxiety among participants who completed more than 50% of the mindfulness course, but no significant changes in depression scores.
population_specificity: Hospitalized high-risk pregnant women (n=68).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of the e-mental health intervention 'CoPE It,' which includes mindfulness-based techniques, in reducing distress and improving mental health outcomes during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study evaluated the intervention's impact on distress, depression, anxiety, self-efficacy, quality of life, and mindfulness, but specific results regarding mindfulness effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adult participants in Germany with adequate German language and computer skills, recruited via emergency support hotlines.
effective_dosage: Four 30-minute modules conducted every other day.
study_duration: The intervention lasted approximately 8 days (4 modules every other day), with follow-ups at 1 and 3 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of psychosocial interventions, including mindfulness, in reducing caregiver burden for informal caregivers of cancer patients.
results_summary: The abstract notes a paucity of evidence for mindfulness interventions, with methodological quality being variable across studies. No specific results for mindfulness were highlighted.
population_specificity: Informal caregivers of individuals affected by cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ESRT, a tailored mindfulness-based intervention, on perceived stress, executive function, well-being, and pro-inflammatory gene expression in first-year surgical and mixed specialty resident trainees.
results_summary: ESRT did not affect perceived stress but improved executive function and mindfulness in surgical trainees (ESRT-1) and reduced emotional exhaustion and depersonalization in mixed specialty trainees (ESRT-2). Pooled analysis showed reduced pro-inflammatory gene expression in ESRT-treated participants compared to controls.
population_specificity: First-year surgical (ESRT-1) and mixed specialty (ESRT-2) resident trainees.
effective_dosage: ESRT-1: 8 weekly 2-hour classes; ESRT-2: 6 weekly 90-minute classes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the treatment and management-related functionality of high-rated mobile apps for anxiety, including those using mindfulness approaches.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness was one of several approaches used in anxiety apps, alongside meditation, breathing exercises, and cognitive behavioral therapy. Apps incorporating mindfulness showed potential as tools for managing anxiety, particularly in overcoming barriers to mental health care.
population_specificity: Individuals with anxiety, stress, depression, sleep issues, or eating disorders using mobile apps.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate interventions, including mindfulness-based training, to improve humanism in surgery by addressing empathy and reducing burnout among surgical trainees.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based training was found to consistently improve rates of burnout among surgical trainees, alongside other interventions like empathetic communication workshops. Overall, 70% of the studied interventions successfully improved empathy in trainees.
population_specificity: Surgical trainees at varying levels of training (total n=1763).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of psychological skills training (PST) and mindfulness training (MT) on psychological variables relevant to athletic performance, such as handling emotions and attention control.
results_summary: Both PST and MT improved the ability to manage emotions and control attention, with MT showing a differential effect in reducing experiential avoidance. Shared improvements were also noted in dealing with failure, though to a lesser extent.
population_specificity: 95 athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) with reductions in anxiety severity in patients with cancer.
results_summary: MBIs were associated with significant reductions in short-term and medium-term anxiety and depression, as well as improved health-related quality of life in adults with cancer, but no long-term anxiety reduction was observed.
population_specificity: Adults with cancer (no trials included children).
study_duration: Short-term (up to 1 month), medium-term (1 to ≤6 months), and long-term (>6 to 12 months) postintervention assessments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review studies on the effectiveness of mindfulness in treating substance use disorders (SUD) in individuals with mild intellectual disability or borderline intellectual functioning (MID-BIF).
results_summary: The abstract mentions that mindfulness was one of the treatments used for SUD in individuals with MID-BIF, but no specific results on its effectiveness were detailed. Only 9.4% of studies reviewed mentioned the co-morbidity of PTSD and SUD, highlighting a gap in integrated treatment research.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild intellectual disability or borderline intellectual functioning (MID-BIF; IQ 50-85).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of mindfulness as a nonpharmacologic treatment option for chronic insomnia disorder.
results_summary: The abstract mentions mindfulness as part of integrative medicine approaches for insomnia but does not provide specific efficacy data. It highlights the growing use of nonpharmacologic treatments, including mindfulness, in clinical practice.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic insomnia disorder, particularly those with other neurologic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining a brief mindfulness meditation with a values session (mindfulness+values) was more effective than values alone in reducing depression symptoms.
results_summary: Mindfulness+values significantly reduced depression more than values alone, particularly for individuals with high baseline depression levels. No difference was found for those with low depression, and values-only participants had higher-than-expected deterioration rates.
population_specificity: 206 participants (baseline depression levels varied; online, self-help setting).
effective_dosage: 10-minute mindfulness meditation daily for 2 weeks, followed by a single values session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update a systematic review on the outcomes of randomized controlled trials of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) for substance use disorders and examine session-by-session protocols.
results_summary: MBIs were found to be as effective as existing evidence-based treatments for reducing substance use frequency and quantity, substance-related problems, and cravings, while increasing abstinence rates.
population_specificity: Individuals seeking treatment for substance use disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of psychotherapy, including mindfulness, on quality of life in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: Among the psychotherapeutic interventions studied, mindfulness was one modality that showed positive effects on quality of life in patients with IBD, though the results were not as consistently positive as cognitive-behavioral therapy. All studies focusing on patients with active disease reported a positive effect of psychotherapy, including mindfulness.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥18 years with active or inactive inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) or focused-breathing interventions used to treat symptoms in children receiving cancer therapy.
results_summary: MBIs, including controlled breathing and belly breathing, were found beneficial for symptoms like procedural pain, distress, and quality of life. The interventions were generally well accepted, though studies had methodological flaws like small sample sizes and lack of randomization.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate participant adherence and smoking cessation outcomes using a self-administered digital intervention combining virtual reality and mindfulness.
results_summary: The treatment group reported 23% abstinence post-intervention compared to 5% in the control group, a statistically significant difference. Adherence was high, but long-term efficacy and feasibility of follow-up procedures for controls need improvement.
population_specificity: 120 participants from Buenos Aires, Argentina (mean age 43.20 years, 47.5% female).
effective_dosage: 21-day program with VR mindful exposure therapy sessions, daily surveys, and online peer-to-peer support.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of an acceptance and commitment therapy-based group intervention, delivered via videoconferencing, in reducing posttraumatic stress symptoms (PTSS) in parents of children with life-threatening illnesses.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly greater improvements in PTSS compared to the waiting list control group, with a large effect size (Cohen d = 1.10). The study supports the use of acceptance and commitment therapy to reduce PTSS in this population, particularly in hard-to-reach groups like fathers and rural caregivers.
population_specificity: Parents of children aged 0-18 years admitted for life-threatening illnesses or injuries in oncology, cardiology, or pediatric intensive care departments.
effective_dosage: 6-session group therapy program delivered over 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of enhanced mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR+) versus stress management for headache (SMH) in reducing headache days and related disability in adults with episodic migraine.
results_summary: MBSR+ showed greater reduction in headache days and disability compared to SMH at 20 weeks, with 52% of MBSR+ participants achieving a 50% reduction in headache days versus 23% in SMH. No differences were observed in clinical outcomes at 52 weeks or MRI outcomes at 20 weeks, though cognitive network changes were noted with MBSR+.
population_specificity: 98 adults with episodic migraine recruited at a single academic center.
effective_dosage: Weekly group sessions for 8 weeks, then biweekly for another 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on acute pain outcomes, including pain severity, threshold, tolerance, and pain-related distress.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of MBIs on pain severity or pain-related distress in clinical or experimental settings, but there was moderate evidence for increased pain tolerance and weak evidence for improved pain threshold in experimental studies. The overall quality of evidence was low or very low for most outcomes.
population_specificity: People with acute pain in clinical and experimental settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of structural changes in hippocampal subfields following mindfulness training and its association with fear extinction and self-reported anxiety.
results_summary: Mindfulness training was associated with increased subiculum volume and decreased hippocampal connectivity to lateral occipital regions during contextual fear retrieval, as well as reduced self-reported anxiety. The findings suggest mindfulness may enhance resilience by modulating hippocampal circuits involved in memory retrieval.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review cognitive flexibility deficits in children and adolescents with critical congenital heart disease (CHD) and provide evidence-based recommendations to support its development.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss Mindfulness or its effects; it focuses on cognitive flexibility deficits in CHD patients and recommendations for intervention.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with critical congenital heart disease (CHD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) in patients with treatment-resistant depression (TRD).
results_summary: MBCT significantly reduced depression and ruminative thinking in the experimental group and improved mediators like mindfulness and self-compassion. Patients maintained these gains over a one-month follow-up period.
population_specificity: Twenty-four patients with treatment-resistant depression.
study_duration: Eight sessions with a one-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the mechanisms and therapeutic factors contributing to pain-related outcome changes in chronic low back pain patients undergoing cognitive therapy, mindfulness meditation, or mindfulness-based cognitive therapy.
results_summary: The study found large effect size changes in pain control beliefs, pain catastrophizing, and pain interference across all three treatments. Therapeutic alliance was associated with pain intensity improvement, while mindful observing, group cohesion, and at-home practice were not significantly linked to outcomes.
population_specificity: Chronic low back pain patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of resilience training, including mindfulness-based interventions, on healthcare students' resilience, mental health, and well-being.
results_summary: The study found very-low certainty evidence that resilience training, including mindfulness, may improve resilience and reduce anxiety and stress perception in healthcare students, but showed little to no effect on depression or well-being.
population_specificity: Healthcare students (medical, nursing, psychology, social work, etc.), primarily young adults (mean age 19.5–38.14 years) and mostly women (63.3%–67.3%).
study_duration: Varied, with high-intensity interventions (>12 hours/sessions) in some studies.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the role of prostaglandin in periodontal diseases and the effect of aspirin on cyclooxygenase inactivation.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that prostaglandin is involved in chronic inflammatory diseases like periodontitis and that aspirin inactivates cyclooxygenase, which produces PGE. No direct results about mouthwash are provided.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The study does not address Mouthwash; it focuses on the safety and tolerability of combining eribulin and everolimus in patients with metastatic triple-negative breast cancer.
results_summary: The study does not provide any results related to Mouthwash.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic triple-negative breast cancer who had up to four lines of prior chemotherapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a natural-ingredient mouthwash in promoting wound healing and reducing complications after oral surgery (extraction).
results_summary: The experimental group showed appreciable wound healing compared to the control, with no adverse effects reported. Patient satisfaction and objective outcomes were significantly better in the experimental group after four weeks.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing routine oral surgery (extraction).
study_duration: Evaluated at ten and thirty days post-extraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of dexamethasone sodium phosphate mouthwash in reducing stomatitis incidence in patients undergoing targeted oncological therapy with everolimus.
results_summary: The study found that a 0.1mg/mL (0.01%) dexamethasone sodium phosphate mouthwash significantly reduced stomatitis incidence when used prophylactically during everolimus treatment, as supported by the SWISH study and European Society for Medical Oncology guidelines.
population_specificity: Patients receiving targeted oncological therapy with everolimus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a citric acid mouthwash versus malic acid lozenges on xerostomia relief, salivary secretion, and oral health-related quality of life in Sjögren's syndrome patients.
results_summary: The citric acid mouthwash improved xerostomia symptoms and salivary output, but the malic acid lozenge showed greater efficacy in both measures and quality of life improvement. The mouthwash's effects were statistically significant but less pronounced than the lozenge.
population_specificity: 110 Sjögren's syndrome patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of sesame oil, ozonated sesame oil, and chlorhexidine mouthwash on improving oral health in adolescents.
results_summary: All groups showed statistically significant reductions in debris, calculus, oral hygiene indices, plaque, and Streptococcus mutans counts after 15 days, with oil pulling (sesame oil and ozonated sesame oil) demonstrating significant oral hygiene improvement.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12-14 years with a decay-missing-filled index ≤3.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved mouth rinses for 15 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-biofilm and anti-inflammatory effects of Melaleuca alternifolia (MEL) nanoparticles with 0.12% chlorhexidine gluconate (CHX) on biofilm-free and biofilm-covered surfaces.
results_summary: CHX showed significantly lower plaque index scores on both biofilm-free and biofilm-covered surfaces compared to MEL, and reduced gingival crevicular fluid volume on biofilm-free surfaces. MEL demonstrated similar anti-inflammatory effects to CHX, but CHX was perceived as having better taste and biofilm control despite causing greater taste changes.
population_specificity: 60 participants who refrained from oral hygiene for 72 hours before the study.
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants rinsed with MEL or CHX for four days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and preliminary efficacy of EGCG mouthwash in reducing radiation-induced oral mucositis in head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that EGCG mouthwash was safe, with minimal toxicities (burning and nausea), and significantly reduced mucositis-related pain scores. The maximum tolerated dose was 2200 μmol/L, and no patients experienced severe mucositis.
population_specificity: Patients with pathologically confirmed head and neck cancer.
effective_dosage: Starting at 440 μmol/L, three times a day, escalated to a maximum of 2200 μmol/L.
study_duration: Weekly assessments during radiotherapy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of a 1% amitriptyline mouthwash formulation on clinical parameters and inflammatory biomarkers in patients with periodontal diseases.
results_summary: The 1% amitriptyline mouthwash significantly reduced periodontal parameters and inflammatory biomarkers (p<0.001) compared to standard treatment alone, demonstrating high efficacy in treating periodontal diseases.
population_specificity: 30 patients with periodontal diseases (gingivitis and periodontitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tranexamic acid (TXA) mouthwash reduces bleeding after dental extraction in patients taking non-vitamin K oral anticoagulants (NOAC).
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so results are not yet available. It will assess oral bleeding, procedural bleeding scores, reinterventions, and interruptions in NOAC treatment. Safety outcomes include non-oral bleeding and thrombotic events.
population_specificity: Patients listed for dental extraction and treated with NOAC.
effective_dosage: 10% TXA mouthwash, used before extraction and three times daily for three days post-extraction.
study_duration: Three days post-extraction, with a seven-day follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether good oral hygiene, including daily antiseptic mouthwash, could improve rheumatoid arthritis (RA) activity.
results_summary: The study found that oral hygiene interventions, including mouthwash, significantly reduced periodontal pathogens but did not significantly decrease RA activity. Patients with baseline periodontal disease or those who became negative for certain bacteria showed a slightly greater reduction in RA activity.
population_specificity: Patients with RA according to ACR/EULAR 2010 criteria from the French early arthritis ESPOIR cohort.
effective_dosage: Daily antiseptic mouthwash (specific product or concentration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether the use of mouthwash was associated with oral cancer risk, alongside other oral health indicators and demographic variables.
results_summary: The study found that no use of mouthwash was a significant predictor of oral cancer, alongside poor oral hygiene, periodontal diseases, and smoking. The association was statistically significant (p<0.05).
population_specificity: Pathologically confirmed oral cancer patients (cases) and ethnically/linguistically-matched controls without oral pathology in Peshawar, Pakistan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) in reducing pain associated with recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS) compared to chlorhexidine (CHX).
results_summary: A single application of NAC resulted in a clinically significant reduction in RAS-associated pain within one day and was more effective than CHX. Pain improvement was greater with NAC on the second day (-3.0 ± 2.0 vs. -1.8 ± 1.9).
population_specificity: 58 patients (57% female, 59% married, 50% with family history of aphthae, 88% with minor RAS) aged 28 ± 9.7 years.
effective_dosage: 200 mg NAC dissolved in water, single application.
study_duration: Single application, effects measured over at least two days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the nitrate-reducing activity of oral bacteria, inhibited by antibacterial mouthwash, plays a key role in post-exercise hypotension (PEH).
results_summary: The study found that antibacterial mouthwash attenuated the blood pressure-lowering effect of exercise by 61% at 1 hour and fully at 2 hours, associated with impaired nitrite synthesis and microvascular response, while placebo mouthwash did not.
population_specificity: 23 healthy individuals (15 males, 8 females)
study_duration: Measurements taken before, 1 hour, and 2 hours after exercise
